Title: UK PM Rishi SunakтАЩs trade talks with India: a possible conflict of interest
Content:
Image: IANS

UK prime minister Rishi Sunak faces a new conflict of interest row before the G20 summit in New Delhi next month over claims that his family could stand to benefit financially from a post-Brexit trade deal that he is negotiating with India, the media reported.

MPs and trade experts say there are concerns at the highest levels of government over potential тАЬtransparencyтАЭ issues relating to his wife Akshata Murty's shareholding- worth almost ┬г500 m- in the massive Bengaluru-based international IT services and consultancy company Infosys, according to reports.

Labour, and the chair of the all-party House of Commons business and trade select committee, called on the night of Aug 26 for Sunak to be more open about his wifeтАЩs financial interests, given that Infosys could be a key beneficiary of any agreement. One leading expert said he should recuse himself from the trade negotiations altogether.

Darren Jones, the Labour chair of the business and trade select committee, said, тАЬAs the prime minister recently learned, itтАЩs important he declares any interests properly. I expect him to do so in respect of the India trade deal too.тАЭ

The calls come as former culture secretary Nadine Dorries, a vocal critic of the prime minister, finally handed in her resignation as an MP, local media reported.

Sunak will attend the G20 summit in New Delhi in two weeks and is expected to discuss the UK-India trade negotiations in a separate bilateral meeting with IndiaтАЩs prime minister, Narendra Modi.

Trade secretary Kemi Badenoch flew back from India this weekend after holding intensive talks on the prospective deal, according to reports.

Infosys, which has had contracts with the British government as well as many UK companies, is known to want to improve access to this country for its many thousands of contract workers through changes to the UK visa regime.

Allowing more visas for its workers in sectors such as IT and artificial intelligence is a key Indian demand in the talks over a free-trade agreement.

The UK, for its part, is seeking reductions in the high tariffs on exports to India of goods including Scotch whisky and cars, stated the reports.

(Source: IANS)

Title: I want to thank the people of India for staying up late, says World champ Neeraj Chopra
Content:
Image: IANS

World Champion Neeraj Chopra today thanked Indian fans for staying up late and watching his event. Neeraj won a historic maiden gold medal for India in the World Athletics Championships, claiming the top spot in the menтАЩs javelin throw competition in Budapest.

His event started at 11:45 p.m. IST (On Sunday) and lasted until 1 a.m. at night. 

Speaking to the reporters after the event, Chopra thanked the Indian fans and said that it was a medal for the country.

тАЬI want to thank the people of India for staying up late. This medal is for all of India. IтАЩm Olympic champion now IтАЩm world champion. Keep working hard in different fields. We have to make a name in the world,тАЭ Neeraj said.

Neeraj, who has been bothered by an injury in the last few months, killed the competition in the Hungarian capital with a massive throw of 88.17 metre (m) in his second turn.

PakistanтАЩs Arshad Nadeem took the silver medal, the first World Championship medal for his country, with a distance of 87.82m while Czech RepublicтАЩs Yakub Vadlejch retained the bronze he won in Oregon last year, with a distance of 86.67m.

The two other Indians in the fray too did their best but could not finish on the podium -- Kishore Kumar Jena, who had to overcome visa problems to reach Budapest, finished fifth with a personal best throw of 84.77m while DP Manu finished sixth with 84.14m.

But India had the most hopes from Neeraj Chopra and the 25-year-old from Haryana did not disappoint as he came up with a superb throw on his second turn and secured his first World Championship gold.

Before Sunday, no Indian male or female had won a gold medal in the World Championship with Anju Bobby George claiming bronze in womenтАЩs long jump at Paris in 2003 while Neeraj Chopra won a silver in Oregon, US, last year.

Chopra, who usually aims to start with a big first throw and had done just that in the qualifying stage with a stunning 88.77 metre, opened with a foul on his first attempt on Sunday.

But his next throw straight away catapulted him to the top of the standings as the 25-year-old Tokyo Olympic gold medallist from Haryana hurled the spear to 88.17m to take the lead.

GermanyтАЩs Julian Weber was placed second with 85.79m on his second attempt while Yakub Vadlejch of the Czech Republic was placed third with 84.18m throw in his second attempt.

Chopra could manage only 86.32m in his third attempt while PakistanтАЩs Arshad Nadeem jumped into the fray with a superb throw of 87.82m on his third turn.

Nadeem, who had surgery on his shoulder earlier this year following an injury, started with a gentle loosener of 74.90m and followed that up with 82.81m before unleashing a rip-roaring 87.82m in his third turn, a season-best for the Pakistan thrower.

IndiaтАЩs DP Manu also came up with his best effort of the first half of the competition with 83.72m in his third attempt and was placed fifth while Kishore Kumar Jena came up with 82.82m in his second attempt to remain in seventh position.

Chopra could manage only an 84.62m throw in his fourth attempt while Nadeem came up with 87.15m while Julian Weber of Germany remained in the third position thanks to his 85.7m attempt.

Arshad Nadem made a final attempt in the sixth round with a big one but it was still short of what he wanted and Chopra sealed the gold medal. 

It has been an indifferent year so far for Neeraj Chopra in 2023 as he has participated in only two competitions with the 88.67m at Doha Diamond League, his best for the season. 

(Source: IANS)

India's Olympic champion Neeraj Chopra won a historic maiden gold medal for India in the World Athletics Championships today, claiming the gold medal in the men's javelin throw competition in Budapest.

Chopra, who has been bothered by an injury in the last few months, killed the competition in the Hungarian capital with a massive throw of 88.17 in his second turn.

Before this, no Indian male or female had won a gold medal in the World Championship with Anju Bobby George claiming bronze in women's long jump at Paris in 2003 while Neeraj Chopra won a silver in Oregon, US, last year.

The second turn did the wonders

India had the most hopes from Neeraj Chopra and the 25-year-old from Haryana did not disappoint as he came up with a superb throw on his second turn and secured his first World Championship gold.

Chopra, who usually aims to start with a big first throw and had done just that in the qualifying stage with a stunning 88.77 metre, opened with a foul on his first attempt on Sunday.

But his next throw straight away catapulted him to the top of the standings as the 25-year-old Tokyo Olympic gold medallist from Haryana hurled the spear to 88.17 to take the lead.

It has been an indifferent year so far for Neeraj Chopra in 2023 as he has participated in only two competitions with the 88.67m at Doha Diamond League, his best for the season.

Pakistan wins a silver

Pakistan's Arshad Nadeem took the silver medal, the first World Championship medal for his country, with a distance of 87.82 while Czech Republic's Yakub Vadlejch retained the bronze he won in Oregon last year, with a distance of 86.67.

Germany's Julian Weber was placed second with 85.79 on his second attempt while Yakub Vadlejch of the Czech Republic was placed third with 84.18m throw in his second attempt.

Chopra could manage only 86.32 metre in his third attempt while Pakistan's Arshad Nadeem jumped into the fray with a superb throw of 87.82 metre on his third turn.

Nadeem, who had surgery on his shoulder earlier this year following an injury, started with a gentle loosener of 74.90m and followed that up with 82.81m before unleashing a rip-roaring 87.82 in his third turn, a season-best for the Pakistan thrower.

Chopra could manage only an 84.62m throw in his fourth attempt while Nadeem came up with 87.15m while Julian Weber of Germany remained in the third position thanks to his 85.7 attempt.

Arshad Nadem made a final attempt in the sixth round with a big one but it was still short of what he wanted and Chopra sealed the gold medal.

Two Indians in the fifth and seventh position

The two other Indians in the fray too did their best but could not finish on the podium- Kishore Kumar Jena, who had to overcome visa problems to reach Budapest, finished fifth with a personal best throw of 84.77 while DP Manu finished sixth with 84.14.

India's DP Manu also came up with his best effort of the first half of the competition with 83.72m in his third attempt and was placed fifth while Kishore Kumar Jena came up with 82.82m in his second attempt to remain in seventh position.

(Source: IANS)

Title: Growing list of Indian-origin CEOs at top firms impresses Elon Musk
Content:
Image: IANS

Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk is impressed at the way Indian-origin people have taken over as CEOs of most of the top tech companies, as well as some of the non-tech organisations, and the list is only growing.

By holding top positions, the Indian-origin people are earning millions of dollars which puts them among the highest paid CEOs in the US.

When the World of Statistics posted on X (formerly Twitter) the list of Indian-origin people at top companies, Musk reacted on Aug 25: тАЬImpressiveтАЭ.

His followers reacted, saying тАЬIndians are some of the hardest working peopleтАЭ.

India is even the тАЬCEO of Moon's South Pole,тАЭ a Musk follower chuckled, after the country successfully landed its Chandrayaan-3 Moon mission.

Currently, Sanjay Mehrotra is the CEO of Micron Technology; Shantanu Narayen is the CEO of Adobe; Satya Nadella is Chairman and CEO of Microsoft; Sunder Pichai is the CEO of Alphabet and Google; Jay Chaudhry is the CEO of Zscaler which is a cloud security company; Arvind Krishna is the CEO of IBM; Neal Mohan is the CEO of YouTube; and George Kurian is the CEO of NetApp, among the top tech giants.

Leena Nair broke all barriers by becoming the first ever Indian-origin global CEO of French luxury fashion house, Chanel. While Laxman Narasimhan is the CEO of Starbucks.

Anjali Sud is the CEO of Vimeo, the online video platform and Rangarajan Raghuram is the CEO of VMware.

Meanwhile, Musk is looking forward to visiting India next year, as he plans to establish a Tesla supply chain ecosystem in the country.

(Source: IANS)

Title: Another Hindenburg? Soros-backed group gears up for Indian corporate expos├й!
Content:
Months after Hindenburg Research, the US-based short seller, released a report on the Adani Group, the Organised Crime and Corruption Reporting Project (OCCRP), funded by George Soros and Rockefeller Brothers Fund, is preparing to reveal another тАШexposeтАЩ about some Indian companies, stated a news agency. 

OCCRP is a global network of investigative journalists which тАЬis formed by 24 nonprofit investigative centres... spread across Europe, Africa, Asia and Latin America,тАЭ may publish a report or a series of articles, three sources with knowledge of the matter informed the agency.

Sources said the тАШexposeтАЩ may involve overseas funds investing in the stocks of the corporate house. The identity of the corporate house wasn't immediately known but agencies are said to be keeping a tight vigil on the capital market, stated the report.  

An email sent to OCCRP seeking comments by the news agency PTI remained unanswered.

What to expect from OCCRP?

Founded in 2006, OCCRP claims to specialise in reporting on organised crime and largely publishes these news articles through partnerships with media houses.

On its website, OCCRP identifies Open Society Foundations of George Soros, as one of its institutional donors. Others include Ford Foundation, Rockefeller Brothers Fund and Oak Foundation.

The Adani-Hindenburg row

The Hindenburg Research that came out seven months ago, accused Adani Group of stock manipulation and improper use of tax havens. Stock market of the group tumbled that erased close to USD 150 billion in the market value at its lowest point.

Adani Group has denied all allegations.
